alert.note: Alert for Anoka (Minnesota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 19 at 10:47AM CDT until May 22 at 1:00AM CDT by NWS Minneapolis
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Minnesota and Wisconsin... Minnesota River at Savage affecting Dakota, Carver, Scott and Hennepin Counties. Mississippi River near Hastings L/D 2 affecting Dakota, Washington, Pierce and Goodhue Counties. ...The Flood Warning is cancelled for the following rivers in Minnesota... Mississippi River at St. Cloud affecting Sherburne, Stearns and Wright Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Minnesota... Sauk River at St. Cloud affecting Stearns County. South Fork Crow River below Mayer affecting Carver County. Minnesota River At New Ulm affecting Brown, Blue Earth and Nicollet Counties. Minnesota River At Morton affecting Redwood and Renville Counties. Minnesota River at Montevideo affecting Lac qui Parle, Chippewa and Yellow Medicine Counties. Redwood River near Redwood Falls affecting Redwood County. Rum River near St. Francis affecting Anoka County. .Rivers are still elevated from rainfall over the past week. Additional rainfall is expected today, continuing the threat; however, the heaviest rain is expected to fall south of the river basins. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY SUNDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Rum River near St. Francis. * WHEN...Until early Sunday morning. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1030 AM CDT Thursday, the stage was 9.5 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 1030 AM CDT Thursday was 9.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage Saturday morning and continue falling to 5.5 feet Thursday morning. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 9.6 feet on 04/06/1986. &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.
